#Text=Fire Island
#Text=Fire Island is a 32-mile ( 51.5-km ) barrier island off the coast of Long Island in Suffolk County , New York .
#Text=Most of Fire Island National Seashore is on the island .
#Text=Communities
#Text=Kismet - The westernmost village , a haven for singles and partiers that is now becoming more family-oriented .
#Text=Saltaire - A family-oriented village featuring Clam Cove harbor .
#Text=During the summer , the village has many youth sport programs .
#Text=Larger houses than most of the island
#Text=Fair Harbor - Another family-oriented community that appeals to creative artists as well .
#Text=Small house on small lots that are very close to each other .
#Text=Dunewood - A totally planned and residential community .
#Text=Group houses are banned in order to preserve the family oriented atmosphere .
#Text=Lonelyville -
#Text=No longer a lonely place , but with some solitude .
#Text=Atlantique - A very small community with no commercial services .
#Text=Robbins Rest - Another small and relatively isolated place .
#Text=Corneille Estates -
#Text=A small place to the west of Ocean Beach that hosts the island 's school .
#Text=Ocean Beach Village -
#Text=The main tourist destination and cultural center .

#Text=Formerly known as " the Land of No " because of many rules to discourage tourism , the local rules have become more visitor friendly , designed to keep the village as a quality of life destination .
#Text=Seaview - A beautiful and residential area with the tallest trees and great walks .
#Text=Also known as the suburb of Ocean Beach .
#Text=Ocean Bay Park - One of the livelier villages thanks to Flynn 's .
#Text=Point O'Woods - A private and gated community .
#Text=Residents must have children , and have 99-year leases rather than ownership .
#Text=Visitors not permitted .
#Text=Cherry Grove - Once the gay " capital " of Fire Island , now a haven for lesbians , older gay men and those with an artistic flair .
#Text=Fire Island Pines - For urbane gay men .
#Text=A retreat from the real world , with " rolling boardwalks " and natural beauty and late-night discos .
#Text=Water Island - Small , quiet community on the narrowest part of the island .
#Text=Davis Park -
#Text=The most remote , most self-sufficient , birthplace of the " sixish " .
#Text=Tourism is allowed , there is a Town of Brookhaven beach in the middle of the community
#Text=Watch Hill - The largest National Seashore complex with 3 mi ( 4.8 km ) of boardwalks and a campsite .
#Text=Tourists welcome .
#Text=Other destinations
#Text=Sunken Forest at Sailor 's Haven - A primordial holly forest crisscrossed with wooden walkways administered by the national park service
#Text=Fire Island National Seashore —
#Text=Understand
#Text=There are no paved roads going to most of the island and vehicle traffic is not permitted in summer .
#Text=A plan to create a paved road across the island resulted in such resistance that it was abandoned .
#Text=Over the years each of the island 's seventeen communities has developed its own unique personality .
#Text=Several of the villages restrict access by tourists or do all they can to be unwelcoming of tourists .
#Text=If you are visiting Fire Island , make sure you find the appropriate community to visit .
#Text=In some cases , visiting the state parks , instead of the towns , might be a better solution .
#Text=In addition to the state parks at either end of the island , public bathrooms and snack bars are in the National Seashore facilities at Atlantique , Sailor 's Haven , and Watch Hill .
#Text=Restrooms can also be found in Ocean Beach and Fair Harbor but may be hard to find .

#Text=Fire Island is home to many vacation communities on the western part of the island ( Ocean Beach being the most populous , with the most restaurants and bars that make for an excellent day trip ) .
#Text=The eastern part of the island is home to the largely gay communities of Cherry Grove and Fire Island Pines .

#Text=Bring cash with you on your trip to Fire Island as most businesses will only accept cash payment . ( This includes parking , transportation fees to and from the island , on many of the small on island shops . )
#Text=Get in
#Text=Most of these methods of getting in must be used in combination .
#Text=For example , to reach Fair Harbor from Manhattan , you could take the LIRR , then a taxi from the train to the ferry , and then the ferry to the Island .
#Text=The car methods mentioned are usually only good for day trips , and there is no way to get from the parking lots to the main parts of the island other than walking .
#Text=By air
#Text=The island is about 60 miles from Manhattan ( the drive can range anywhere from 1-4 hr based on traffic .
#Text=It averages about 1½ hr ) .
#Text=You can fly into LaGuardia or Kennedy Airports in New York City or Islip MacArthur Airport on Long Island , then use a rental car , taxi , or train to your destination .
#Text=By car
#Text=There are only two bridges to Fire Island .
#Text=The Robert Moses Causeway on the western end of Fire Island leads to parking lots at Robert Moses State Park .
#Text=The William Floyd Parkway leads to Smith Point County Park on the eastern end of Fire Island , where there are also parking lots ( fees charged ) .
#Text=Fire Island has no public roads .
#Text=Tommy 's Taxis , +1 631-665-4800 , also goes direct from Manhattan .
#Text=$ 18 ( or $ 21 Sundays and holidays )
#Text=By bus
#Text=Suffolk County Transit , +1 631-852-5200 .
#Text=Operates bus routes to provide access to the island 's gateway communities , but you 'll have to walk or take a taxi to get to your destination .
#Text=By train
#Text=Long Island Rail Road , +1 631-231-5477 .
#Text=Has stations are near three ferry terminals : Patchogue , Sayville , and Bay Shore .
#Text=All have taxi service to the ferry terminals .
#Text=By boat
#Text=Ferries to Fire Island depart from the following locations : Sayville and Bay Shore ( villages of Islip ) and Patchogue ( a village of Brookhaven ) .
#Text=Water taxis are available if you miss the ferry .
#Text=Fire Island Ferries , 99 Maple St , ☏ +1 631-665-3600 .
#Text=Bay Shore .
#Text=Year round to Ocean Beach , Fair Harbor , Dunewood , Atlantique , Kismet , Saltaire , Ocean Bay Park and Seaview .
#Text=Sayville Ferries , 41 River Road .
#Text=Year round to Cherry Grove , Fire Island Pines , Sunken Forest and Water Island .
#Text=Patchogue Ferries , +1 631-475-1665 .
#Text=Mid-March to November from two ferry terminals in Patchogue .
#Text=Leaves from County Road 83 to Davis Park ; and from County Road 19 to Watch Hill in the Fire Island National Seashore park .
#Text=Many Fire Island sites can be reached by private boat from the Great South Bay , with marinas at Watch Hill , Sailors Haven and most island communities .
#Text=The bay is shallow , and boaters occasionally moor offshore .
#Text=When on Fire Island , water taxis can shuttle you from point to point .
#Text=Western Fire Island is reachable by ferry from Bay Shore on Long Island .
#Text=Bay Shore is about an hour train ride on the Long Island Railroad from Manhattan , and the ferry ride from Bay Shore is another 30 minutes .
#Text=Ferries to Ocean Beach from Bay Shore run about once every hour during the summer .
#Text=Cherry Grove and the Fire Island Pines are reachable by ferry from Sayville .
#Text=The easternmost community , Davis Park , is reachable by ferry from Patchogue .
